ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Yes, absolutely - especially for people interested in moving images and/or broadening their visual tools.

This class is a rollercoaster of intense happiness and intense suffering. It is entirely focused on learning the 3-D digital animation program Maya, and it is simultaneously super enjoyable and utterly depressing: Maya is such a difficult program to work with, but when you get something to move how you want it, it's amazing. I can see years of work ahead of me if I want to make the 3-minute animation I had originally planned out as a storyboard for the class' midterm. How can sitting in front of a computer screen staring at a digital mesh and moving points on it around for five hours be exhilarating? Somehow it is. Johannes is an amazing instructor and really brings a sense of fun to the course; he is a walking encyclopedia of animation throughout the ages, too. It's too bad there isn't much time for discussion of the theory/history of digital animation because of how much there is to learn in Maya itself, but omg you really do learn a lot. Be prepared to not sleep and eat only erratically for the last month of the course especially. This is a real time suck, but it is worth every second.
